back: For a matrix $M$, a row $m_{k*}$ is a linear combination of the other rows if there are constants $c_i$ such that \begin{equation*} \mathbf{m}_{k*} = \sum_{i \ne k} c_i \mathbf{m}_{i*} . \end{equation*} An equivalent definition applies to columns.
A collection of vectors $\mathbf{v}_0, \mathbf{v}_1, \ldots \mathbf{v}_{n-1}$ is linearly dependent if at least one of $\mathbf{v}_k$ can be written as a linear combination of the other vectors.
A collection of vectors $\mathbf{v}_0, \mathbf{v}_1, \ldots \mathbf{v}_{n-1}$ is linearly independent if none of the vectors can be written as a linear combination of the other vectors.
The number of linearly independent rows and columns of a matrix.
A matrix that has the maximum possible rank (equal to the minimum of the number of rows and number of columns).
A matrix that is not full rank: its rank is smaller than the maximum possible.
